page.title: 06PILTANTON BURN
page.content: The burn then narrows again and the water once more becomes cloudy. The amount of weeds increases as does the slime. There is also a distinct smell of{rotten eggs}where the burn is joined by a tributaary which flows from{GARTLAND MAINS.} Some of the sources which contribute to the pollution were, the discharge from sewage works at Lochans village; the dumping of rubbish on the banks; farm drainage{e.g. silage and manure {effluent;}field drainage; stagnant water entering the burn. This suggests that as the burn continues the amount of pollution increases. This is demonstrated by the clouding water, and the addition of a foul smell as the burn leaves the area. The only sign of litter however was in the village.
